title: Powerlifting Meet Structure
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Powerlifting meets consist of 3 squats, 3 bench presses, and 3 deadlifts. The time between lifts can vary, but usually, you get at least 30 minutes between lifts. They run it so there are no real breaks for spectators. While the other folks are lifting, you’re warming up and getting ready. Usually between the lifts (squat and bench press) we’ll have 30-60 minutes.

title: Maximizing Performance During a Meet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Between the actual attempts (1st, 2nd, & 3rd) themselves, Layne will take a drink of water or might eat some candy quickly if he feels like he needs it. For the most part, he’s mentally trying to get himself in the right zone. Timing is a big thing because when they call “bar is loaded,” you have 1 minute to get the down command for squat or bench press or whatever it is. He likes to have 2-3 minutes to get very aroused and amped up. He’ll do visualization and breath work in the last few minutes leading up to his lift. He wants to have his heart rate around 160-170 by the time he goes out to hit his lift.

title: Perception and Anxiety in Competition
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne notes, “Your stress hormones are going to be high… This is a little bit off topic, but I was listening to a sports psychologist talk about how the differences between excitement and anxiety and anxiousness, you can’t almost pick them out. It’s just your perception.” He relates it to watching an episode of The Ultimate Fighter many years ago where it was Matt Serra versus Matt Hughes. That reframing of things and just accepting and being okay with the anxiety has helped Layne so much. “Ever since then, it completely flipped the way I looked at competition… And now, when I feel those nerves start to kick in, I just tell myself  ‘this is a good thing, this is a good thing. This is your body getting you ready.’”‒ Layne Norton

title: Injury Risk in Powerlifting Meets
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter notes the stakes in powerlifting are really high and the meet is really short. He wonders if the stakes are high from an injury standpoint because you’re pushing at your limit. Layne does not mention any injuries he has sustained during a meet.

title: Injury Risk in Powerlifting
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Injury is definitely one of the things that is part of the game. You’re going to deal with pain. Layne always tells people “I’m 40 now, and most 40 year olds, 50 year olds, they have pain anyway. So I’d rather be strong and have pain than be weak and have pain.” Layne guesses it’s less frequent to get injured at meets than during training. When you’re in the throes of training and you have high levels of fatigue, maybe you’re just not able to execute the lifts as well (because of that fatigue), and that’s where things tend to happen. Especially if you’re doing multiple repetitions. As you get close to the failure, there is the opportunity to get out of position or make mistakes.

title: Peaking for Powerlifting Meets
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: How many times a year can you peak for a meet at the top level of powerlifting? Layne has done 1 per year and 4 per year (high level meets). 4 is way too much. He thinks the sweet spot for him is probably 2. Really, it’s about getting to competition day with enough fitness level, in terms of being able to execute heavy lifts, while dissipating fatigue and being in low enough levels of pain that you can execute. Afterwards when he feels good after a meet is the most dangerous because he tends to go right back into training. The smart thing to do is take some time to train for fun, keep that core strength, but move  towards accessory movements and things that don’t beat you up so much for several months. Then you could re-enter more of a building/ accumulation phase. Where the volume is going up, but the weights still aren’t super heavy. In those last 3 months, at the end of his training in preparation for competition, he ramps up to more heavy weights. He’s mostly hitting heavy singles.

title: Training for Strength and Longevity
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter notes the 2 metrics most significantly associated with longevity are strength and cardiorespiratory fitness (as measured by VO2 max). Being weak, relative to being strong, is about 250%. Having a very low Vo2 max in the bottom 25% of the population versus being in the top 2.5% of the population is about 400%. The 3rd thing that stands out is muscle mass. But when you look at the data, you realize muscle mass is tightly associated with strength. For listeners whose eyes are sort of glazing over as they talk about powerlifting, it’s worth pointing out that even if you never do a heavy squat, heavy bench press, or heavy deadlift, you have to be strong. These associations show up over and over again in studies. They use measures like grip strength, bench press, leg extension. It becomes important for people to understand how to train for power. Layne notes, “The principles are pretty much the same, it’s just the level to which they’re applied. And I think it’s important to point out that there are diminishing returns with strength.” Risk of injury is also something you want to avoid.

title: The Importance of Progressive Overload
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: As far as strength goes, the most important core principle is progressive overload. People can achieve this by adding more weight, increasing repetitions, or doing more hard sets. Another effective form of progressive overload is increasing the reps. When people hear this, many just think “weight on the bar”. But when you’re getting started, just putting more weight on the bar every week is a perfectly reasonable way to progress. Layne Norton agrees that you’re always weighing those 2 things, your stimulus versus fatigue ratio.

title: Progressive Overload for Everyone
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: People will say, “Well, I’m postmenopausal woman” or “I’m a 75 year old male. It’s too late for me.” No it’s not. Now is the best time. Layne Norton conducted a study on frail elderly people (who almost couldn’t walk) and used progressive overload. In 12 weeks, they had people who could squat down to a below parallel chair and come back up (which is really something for a frail elderly person).

title: Stimulus vs Fatigue Ratio
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter notes, “This is one thing that, from one of our earlier discussions, that really started to change my training. I started adding a little bit more sets at slightly lower RPE to net increase volume.” Layne agrees, “You’re always weighing those 2 things, your stimulus versus fatigue ratio”. Layne is coached by a guy named Zach Robinson, who’s doing his PhD in Mike Zourdos’ lab at FAU. They do a lot of training in the RPE 5-6 area, which some people call easy. When it comes to compound lift, Layne wouldn’t really call it easy, but he thinks about, “How can we maximize our stimulus and minimize fatigue?”

title: RPE and How it Works
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: RPE has been adapted from running to lifting. It’s on a scale of 1-10. At RPE 10, you have no more reps left. This was your absolute 100% effort. At RPE 9, you could have done 1 more rep. At RPE 8, you could have done 2 more reps, so on and so forth. We know you don’t have to train to failure to grow muscle. Training to failure may even be a bit counterproductive in terms of the fatigue it causes relative to the stimulus. For most movements, you get the most hypertrophy and strength benefits going within a few reps of failure (a RPE of 7 or 8).

title: RPE and Estimating Intensity
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Beginners and intermediates tend to underestimate their RPE by about 5, which is pretty incredible. When research makes them take the weight to failure (by yelling at them and encouraging them), on average they’ll get in 5 more reps than they had estimated. The RPE validity in advanced lifters tends to be much more accurate. Layne was at a powerlifting meet where they had a Tendo unit on the bar and were measuring bar velocity as they asked them to rate their RPE after each attempt. They found that RPE, as validated by velocity data, was a pretty good measure in that population of powerlifters, because they’ve taken so many sets near failure. Layne’s summary: “You do need some experience going really hard and really close to failure. But once you have that experience and you understand what that feels like, then you can estimate better. You’re probably better off staying a few reps shy of failure and accumulating volume that way, just because going to failure is just so incredibly fatiguing.”

title: Low-Rep Training and Strength
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: For a person who is not planning to go to a power meet, is there a need for them to go below four reps in training? Probably not, you can get plenty strong even doing sets of 10-15. Now you will not be as strong (even per cross-sectional area) as somebody who trains for strength, because strength is a specific skill. Layne’s best squat was 668 lbs. 6 months out from this, he was able to squat with added weight. But he has not added much more lean body mass. He was practicing the skill of a one rep max (which allowed him to do better on the one rep max). Mostly at 90% for singles, sometimes 95%. His RPE was 8-9. This teaches you how to grind through a lift. Interestingly, the more advanced somebody gets (in terms of strength), the slower their one rep max velocity will be. Research studies show this all the time, somebody who’s kind of new will come in, they will absolutely smoke a weight, then you put 5 lbs on, and they get stapled. Because they don’t have that grind capacity. They don’t know how to do it. Part of it may be psychological, but part of that’s probably physiological too. They haven’t trained their body to recruit all the fibers that it can get. Layne’s summary on strength: Lean body mass and strength are very closely tied together. But when it gets to those finer levels of strength, it’s kind of just practicing the actual one rep max. So when it comes to getting strong, you can absolutely get strong doing sets of 10, 15, because you’re increasing your lean body mass. Do you need to do sets of 3, 4? No. But don’t count them out because a lot of people actually just do really well with variety.

title: Periodization and Adherence
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Periodization (the planned manipulation of training variables (load, sets, and repetitions) in order to maximize training adaptations and to prevent the onset of overtraining syndrome) was kind of a big thing for lifting, back in the day, and now research studies show, it doesn’t appear to produce greater gains in lean body mass. It may provide a little bit better strength gains, but that’s probably just because people peak better when you’re periodizing things. People tend to like periodization better because they’re varying their repetition and are not as bored. “So you never want to poo poo the psychological effects of those things… Adherence is the most important thing.”‒ Layne Norton. Layne always asks people, “Well, what do you enjoy? What’s going to get you to show up consistently?” There are many ways to skin a cat, slightly less technical lifts that are still going to produce really great gains, in terms of strength and lean body mass.

title: Compound Movements
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: How important are compound movements? Do you think there is still an essential need for some sort of compound movement, like a hip thruster, at least as a complement, or a leg press?

title: Importance of compound lifts and variety in strength training
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne emphasizes the importance of compound lifts and variety in strength training. He suggests that different areas of leg muscles are better activated by different exercises, and it's good to have variety. There's also interesting data that suggests that you don't have to get as close to failure on compound lifts to still get the same stimulation compared to isolation exercises. Layne suggests that beginners start with no weight and progress gradually to more complex exercises like barbell squats.

title: Benefits of strength training for longevity and quality of life
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne suggests that the biggest thing in strength training is getting something close and analogous to the things that are going to be important in your day-to-day life as you get older. He emphasizes the risk of falls for seniors and how lifting heavy weights can improve bone density, strength, and balance.

title: Teleological perspective on building muscle mass
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne thinks that people miss the teleological perspective of building muscle mass. He suggests that you have to give your body a reason to lay down tissue, and muscle is energetically expensive. The body wants to keep you alive long enough to reproduce, and once you've done that, it's just trying to prevent you from starving.

title: Protein and Resistance Training for Lean Mass
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: If you eat more protein you can lay done more lean mass, but it’s going to be minimal compared to what you can build through resistance training. When you couple resistance training with high enough protein (or any of these other modalities), now you’re creating the turnover in the tissue, that the body has the requirement to lay down that tissue.

title: Strength Capacity and Aging
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne is stronger today than he was at 20 and he thinks he probably could be as strong now as at age 30. Layne’s lower strength compared to age 35 is not necessarily because he’s losing type II fibers with age, it’s more about his capacity to train due to pain. In the literature, you do see differences between young and old, but most of those get ameliorated when you start adding in resistance training.

title: Gender Differences in Lean Mass and Strength
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Women can gain lean mass and strength just as much as men. Women have been shown to gain just as much lean mass as a percentage of their starting lean mass. The literature shows women can add the same % of lean mass as men, and the same thing for strength. There is some evidence that women may be able to tolerate higher training volumes than men. Layne wonders if this is more of a function of having a smaller body and handling less weight.

title: Testosterone and Muscle Gain
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Men and women have a full log difference in testosterone. Layne thinks one of the main benefits of testosterone is the increase in satellite cell number, which is going to increase your potential for increasing muscle mass. This is a theory called the mononuclear dominant theory, but he doesn’t want to talk about it like it’s set in stone proven.

title: Satellite cells and muscle growth potential
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Satellite cells are quiescent cells that sit on the outside of a muscle fiber. Through various ways (resistance, training, testosterone, whatever), you can get those satellite cells to be donated to the muscle fiber. Muscle fiber is the only cell type that is multinucleated. And we think the reason is each myonuclei can only control protein synthesis for a certain area. The muscle fiber can only grow as big as it has myonuclei. So the more myonuclei you can donate, the greater your potential is. One reason we think that men have more lean mass than women is during puberty hormonal difference emerge, and exposure to testosterone increase the number of myonuclei. This gives men a greater overall potential for lean mass. Up until puberty, males and females tend to have similar amounts of lean mass. So now when you talk about taking exogenous levels of testosterone, now you’re donating even more myonuclei, and so, you can reach a higher ceiling. Layne thinks this is the strongest argument against the crossover of transgender sports for people who were previously male but now identify as female, you can’t get rid of the long term benefit conveyed by the fusion of those myonuclei. He acknowledges this statement might get him in trouble.

title: Muscle memory and testosterone exposure
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Compare it muscle memory‒ if you have trained before but stop training, you can gain back muscle much faster than it takes to build it. This is true even for people who have stopped training for years. Animal study found muscle growth boosted by previous exposure to testosterone. There was a mouse study where they gave the animals testosterone and resistance trained them. One group received testosterone and the other did not. Both groups gained strength and lean mass, but the group getting testosterone gained more. Then they had a washout period, for a long as it took both groups to get back to their original lean mass number. They had both groups train again, without drugs in either group. The group that originally had testosterone gained muscle significantly faster than the other group. Our best understanding is it’s probably these myonuclei that got fused through that extra testosterone that confers that long-term benefit, and that’s how we think about max potential. Do we think that occurs only during a critical window of development, or does that happen if you’re 40 years old and you’re taking exogenous testosterone? We don’t really know because there’s no data on this. Layne speculates that if you have a certain level of testosterone through puberty and now you’re an adult and you maintain that as your natural state (you don’t get too obese or too underweight). You’ve probably fused the amount of myonuclei that you’re going to fuse (at least from testosterone). Now if you start taking testosterone exogenously, you’ve ramped that up another notch. And now you can fuse more myonuclei. Anecdotally, this would make sense because drug use in bodybuilding has continued to go up, up, up. We’re getting to the point where guys aren’t getting much bigger.

title: Layne's Injury and Training Philosophy
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne has been experiencing back, knee, and hip pain, but has learned to listen to his body and back off when necessary. He loves training and feeling strong, but has also learned the importance of discretion and not pushing through pain. He has found a balance between training and avoiding further injury, and has incorporated variations of movements to build strength without exacerbating his pain.

title: Layne's Workout Routine
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne's workout routine varies depending on his pain levels, but he typically trains for 3-4 hours a day. He focuses on movements that stimulate the primary muscles used in competition lifts, but also incorporates variations to build a baseline level of strength. He does heavy singles and builds volume through other areas, and does not do squat, bench press, and deadlift workouts too frequently due to their fatiguing nature.

title: Taking the Psychology Out of Training
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter’s experiment to take the psychology out of training involves having powerlifters lift without knowing the weight on the bar. Their coach would tell them how many reps to do for every set or to what RPE to go until. It would be completely programmed, but take away the psychology and don’t let the athletes suffer from knowing, “Oh, my god, I should be able to do this many reps”. One day they might get down on a bar and the bar is going to be really light and they will be told, “I think you’re going to get 10 reps here. Let’s see it.” Layne knows a guy who completed his entire training cycle that way, Bryce Lewis, one of the top lifters in the world.

title: Nutrition and Weight Cutting for Competitions
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne is sitting very close to the weight class he’s going to compete in so he doesn’t have to make a bunch of changes (he’s 208 lbs). If he was at 215-217 lbs, then it gets to the point where a weight of 205 becomes a little bit untenable. When he competes, it’s a 2 hour weigh-in (2 hours between weigh-in and lifting). So if you cut 10-15 lbs, you’re not going to be able to rehydrate and refuel quickly enough. For Layne, he can cut 2-3, maybe 4% of his body weight, but he doesn’t want to go much more than that because with 2 hours, you just don’t have time. Layne keeps taking creatine because he can modify sodium and fiber to get some water weight out on those last few days. He tries to be a little bit underweight the day before the meet so he can eat enough calories the day before and not feel like he has to shovel food down. On Saturday after weigh-in, he has 2 hours to get food down, but there’s also a lot of other stuff he has to do (like warm-up). He wants his brain to be free to think about the stuff he’s got to do and not thinking about nutrition or electrolytes.

title: Creatine Supplementation
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Creatine is one of the supplements Peter gets the most questions about. Layne keeps taking creatine because he can modify sodium and fiber to get some water weight out on those last few days.

title: Why is creatine important?
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Creatine is a high energy phosphate donor that exists as phosphocreatine in muscle. When you take supplemental creatine, it’ll come into the muscle, and it’ll get a phosphate attached to it (creating phosphocreatine). Originally, the only mechanism for enhancing performance that we thought of, was it’s role as a high energy phosphate donor. Benefits of creatine include increased lean body mass, strength, and cognitive benefits. It is also a really powerful osmolite that pulls water into muscle tissue, which in and of itself may actually be anabolic. Regardless of the mechanism, we do know that when you take creatine, you see improvements in lean mass.

title: Action of creatine
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Creatine (or phosphocreatine) can act as a high energy phosphate donor to regenerate ATP and allow you to perform better. Creatine is also a really powerful osmolite that pulls water into muscle tissue, which in and of itself may actually be anabolic. But regardless of the mechanism, we do know that when you take creatine, you see improvements in lean mass. If you look at anything that improves hypertrophy, a big portion of it is water. A more hydrated cell may be better able to carry out its function. So if the function of a myofibril is contractile, release, contract, release, and it has more water, it seems logical that it’s going to be better at clearing metabolic waste and recruiting fuel, which would at least be 2 things that would factor into its ability to do that.

title: Concerns about creatine
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: You get an increase in creatinine, which can be a marker of renal function. Peter recalls a recent article in JAMA which said we should look at cystatin C instead of creatinine to assess renal function. Some other things can get a bit wonky from lifting weights, like liver enzymes. But just because you have elevated liver enzymes or elevated creatinine, does not mean that you necessarily have damage to those tissues.

title: Creatine Supplementation
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne believes that creatine doesn't affect androgen levels, and there is no evidence that creatine causes changes to hair follicles or hair loss. A recent meta-analysis showed that taking 5 g of creatine a day increases lean mass, strength, and performance. It's hard to compare taking creatine on lifting days versus non-lifting days, but the benefits come from accumulation, so it's key to saturate the muscle cell. Creatine loading can cause bad GI irritation, but it's a trade-off for faster saturation. There's no need to cycle creatine because there's no benefit to coming off as long as intramuscular levels of creatine are not falling.

title: Rep Speed and Time Under Tension
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: There is no discussion of rep speed and time under tension in the given text.

title: Manipulating Mass and Acceleration for Maximal Force
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: If you’re going to press your dumbbells, one school of thought is to press them as quickly as possible. Because the mass is fixed, so any speed of lifting is acceleration because you’re moving against gravity. But the faster you can do it, the greater the force. At some point, the weight becomes so heavy that you increase the effort more on the mass variable than on the acceleration variable. So you can manipulate mass and acceleration to reach maximal force. An extreme example is a one-rep max. But as Layne pointed out earlier, the more elite a powerlifter becomes, the slower it is. So the emphasis is on mass, which is what you get scored on. How do we think about the mixing and matching of the mass versus the acceleration in an effort to optimize force? (on the concentric)

title: Time Under Tension Training
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: For hypertrophy, force is probably less important. It’s more about having enough sufficiently hard sets, however you slice that. The idea of time under tension training was very popular. In the initial research, one study had people doing curls, something around 6 second eccentric, 6 second concentric, to failure. Another group did the normal cadence and match the number of reps in the first group. They found the group doing slow eccentrics and concentrics gained more muscle. If you were going at a normal pace, how many times could you do 30% of a one-rep max (30, 40, 50)? A couple studies recently came out looking at fast eccentrics versus slow eccentrics and found there was a little bit better outcome with fast eccentrics with respect to muscle mass. See the selected links section at the end. Peter notes, “The only time I’ve ever done a fast eccentric is on my Exerfly machine because you’re forced to. It’s pulling you down so quickly that you’re screaming down and you’re coming to a stop. Outside of that it never occurred to me to do an eccentric quickly.” If he’s doing eccentric deadlifts, he’s trying to come down as slowly as possible, thinking that it is more time under tension. Layne thinks the time is part of the lift as well. You don’t want to take it too extreme and dive bomb a squat when there’s no tension on the bar. Consider a bicep curl. Have 2 people curl the same weight, using the same speed on their concentric. 1st person does a 2 sec concentric and 2 sec eccentric. 2nd person does a 2 sec concentric and a 6 sec eccentric. Will the 1st person produce more hypertrophy? Layne thinks it might be better. If you think about mechanical transduction and the force (the mechanical tension being applied to a muscle) when you’re getting to that point where the muscle is stopping and then having to come the other way, if it’s fast, that’s probably more tension at that specific point. So we just don’t know enough about this stuff right now to really be able to say for sure. But there is benefit from slow movements for people who have pain or don’t want to use a heavy weight.

title: Tempo Training
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne has used tempo training pretty liberally in some of his training cycles to make it so he had to use less weight but still keep it difficult. Slow movements still have application for people.

title: Super Slow Protocol
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter has had a couple patients whose disdain for exercise is so great that the most he can negotiate them doing is one 20-30 minute workout per week doing the super slow protocol. They do 8-10 different machines and they only do 1 set and it’s to failure. The sets are typically titrated to be somewhere between 90 and 105 seconds. Super slow is one tool in the toolkit to get some of the benefits from resistance training. Probably not as good as compound movements with a free bar and training at a normal pace, but it’s better than sitting at home and doing nothing.

title: Physiology of Hypertrophy
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: When it comes to the super slope, we still don’t fully understand how the process of muscle hypertrophy occurs. For hypertrophy we know that you need to progressively overload. One of the things we think matters is metabolic stress, this idea that you’re accumulating metabolic byproducts inside the muscle as you work it out. Hence BFR (blood flow restriction). When you’re dealing with that super slow protocol, you’re kind of pushing a little bit more on that metabolic stress as opposed to the mechanical tension portion of it. But there still is mechanical tension. If you’re doing super slow, you might have a light weight, but you also have a really long time that you’re under that light weight accumulating metabolic stress and mechanical tensions. So it makes sense that you would have some of those benefits.

title: Downsides to Super Slow
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The bigger downside is you’re probably not going to get as strong doing that methodology as you are doing a little bit more normal pace.

title: Traditional Strength Training vs Super Slow
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter notes that super slow training may have a little bit less functionality than somebody who’s done kind of more traditional strength training. Peter’s bigger issue with super slow is that he doesn’t think people really can go to failure. It’s really difficult. It’s easier to do an exercise when you don’t have to go to failure, but you make up for in with volume.

title: The Reason Why We Exercise
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The reason why we exercise is to live well. Peter notes, “I do worry that when we rob people of movements that require more than one plane, movements that require balance and some coordination, we’re not giving them the full benefit of the exercise, of the reason to exercise”. Any exercise is better than no exercise.

title: Do Something
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne thinks when a lot of people get into things, they have “paralysis by analysis”. At a certain point, this is an excuse to do nothing. Just go do something. When it comes to people who have been sedentary, Layne asks what they like doing. If the only outcome you’re going for is perfection, few people are going to be able to hit that. A lot of the conversation boils down to this isn’t as good as this, but it’s still better than that. Do we really need optimal to see a benefit? “Do people really need optimal to get out of the state we’re in where so many people have type 2 diabetes and have obesity and are dying from heart disease and cancer?  Honestly, if we can get 50% of the way there, we’ll probably see a huge benefit”‒ Layne Norton.

title: Fitness and Strength Improvement
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter adds, when you divide people into quartiles of fitness and strength, the improvement in benefit always comes from moving from the bottom quartile to the next one. You’re going to achieve the most benefit when you go from being in the lowest 20% of the population to the second 20th percentile population. Layne agrees, “One of the biggest failures of the fitness industry, quite honestly, is convincing people that they need to have a shredded six pack and be really muscular to be fit. No, you don’t have to.”

title: Steps Per Day
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Data on steps per day. The step data is pretty clear, there’s a huge inflection at about 8,000 steps per day. You still get benefits by going up to 20,000 steps a day. But the vast majority of benefits (the drop in mortality) is from going from 2,000 to 8,000 steps. Layne doesn’t think there is anything magic about steps, it’s just looking at people getting more active.

title: Navigating Social Media
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Navigating social media: advice for judging the quality of information from “experts” online. How can a person make sense of the never ending sea of experts out there? A couple years ago Layne had Alan Levinovitz on his podcast. They talked about how hard it is for people to identify experts.

title: What to look for in an expert
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Look for people who sound kind of doubtful and they say things like, “Probably, maybe, possibly.” An expert needs to know the context to be able to answer correctly.

title: The importance of knowing what you don't know
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Part of Layne's PhD program was a qualifying exam. When he was prepping for this, his advisor said, “They’re going to push you in whatever subject they start out on until you don’t know, and you need to be able to say, “I don’t know””. That division puts such an emphasis on not going outside your lane, not speaking about something, not speculating about something that you didn’t know and trying to pass it off like you did.

title: Advice to avoid
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Avoid people who use tips, tricks, hacks, 5 things to never do, 5 things to always do. Avoid people who use superlatives‒ the best, the worst (that’s not how experts talk).

title: Navigating social media
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Social media is negatively selecting, because the flare for showmanship, tips, tricks, and listicles get attention. Social media adds another layer of confusion to this difficult topic. Social media also acts as an information silo.

title: Layne's Personality on Social Media
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne has decided not to get drawn into negative comments on Twitter and doesn't really look at them anymore. He thinks his style isn't for everybody and has the most vitriol for people who post misinformation and clearly have a pattern of behavior where that is being monetized. Layne has had many academics reach out to him behind closed doors and say, “I love your Twitter, I love just watching you break this stuff down”. Layne doesn’t attack people but provides logic, data, and citations. He’s also trying to make it a funny and engaging conversation.

title: Layne's Views on Low-Carb Diets
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne always tells people, “How could I be anti-low-carb? If you go to our nutrition coaching app, Carbon Diet Coach, two of the six settings are low carbohydrate. There’s low carbohydrate and there’s ketogenic.” He thinks this is an example of the Tim Tebow effect, but it’s just polarization. Layne thinks this happens with many different subjects.

title: Low Carb and Fat Loss
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton refutes the claim that low carb is better for fat loss than calorie protein equated diets that are not low carb. He suggests that people choose what they prefer because low carb is not worse. Layne Norton does not enjoy low carb but many people do. People get tribal about low carb because they find something that worked for them and then they retroactively try to find evidence to show that it’s the best thing that there is.

title: Nutrition vs Exercise
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton believes that nutrition is more cult-like than exercise because of the ubiquity of food in our lives and the fact that we all have almost equally a personal relationship with food, whereas not everybody exercises the same amount. People want to validate what they already believe to be true. Everybody has an opinion about nutrition, and it is tough to change people’s beliefs.

title: Changing Beliefs
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton believes that being wrong about something is a beautiful thing because it gives you something to improve on. He has changed his mind about a myriad of things over the years, including LDL cholesterol, branched-chain amino acid supplementation, intermittent fasting, and more.

title: LDL Cholesterol
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton used to believe that the HDL: LDL ratio and the particle size were important for LDL cholesterol. However, after seeing enough Mendelian randomization studies, he realized that the lifetime exposure to LDL is what is important. The mortality rate is linear with the lifetime exposure to LDL. Now he’s a little more conscious about the saturated fat he consumes, and he started taking a low dose of a statin. He probably eats 60-70 grams of fiber a day.

title: LDL and Mendelian Randomization
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter Attia discusses the importance of Mendelian randomization in understanding the impact of HDL and LDL on cardiovascular disease and mortality. He notes that while higher HDL is better for metabolic health, lower LDL is almost always better for cardiovascular disease and mortality. Mendelian randomization allows for a lifetime randomized control, which is crucial when studying a disease that is a lifetime exposure.

title: Supplemental Branched Chain Amino Acids
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton used to be a big advocate for supplemental branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs), but now believes that the cost and negative impact on taste isn't worth it. While there may be a small benefit for delayed onset muscle soreness with BCAAs outside of regular protein, research suggests that whey protein is better than branched-chains, even when you equate the dose of BCAAs in the protein.

title: Intermittent Fasting and Protein Intake
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne used to worry about the catabolic effects of intermittent fasting when combined with resistance training and sufficient total protein. He thinks the caveat in these studies should be that they train within their feeding window. Peter used to be a big proponent of intermittent fasting, but he was seeing a real deterioration of body composition in his patients due to reduced protein intake. Layne thinks people get too hung up on the fasting part of intermittent fasting. The point of intermittent fasting is energy restriction, so what’s an extra 200 calories outside of your feeding window? Layne and Dr. Laymen think breakfast is probably the most important meal for protein dosing of the day because you’re coming off a significant period of fasting.

title: Nuances of Intermittent Fasting
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter thinks autophagy is an incredibly important part of our ability to regenerate, and you’re not getting any meaningful amount of it in 16 hours. So now he tells patients to have a protein shake outside of that feeding window. Layne points out that some of the effects of high protein diets are not dissimilar from fasting in terms of liver metabolism. He’s concerned with having carbohydrates and fats during the fasting period (not protein).

title: Carnivore Diet, Elimination Diets, and Fruits and Vegetables
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: What is the argument for the carnivore diet? It’s a diet where you only eat meat. Layne adds, “The fact that I’m sitting here defending plants, is actually mind blowing to me”. If anything, it should increase your trust in what he’s saying because he is a fan of high quality animal protein.

title: Carnivore Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Some people have said it helped clear up autoimmune issues. That’s hard to quantify. Some people say it lowered their inflammation and GI problems. A lot of people get mixed up and equate getting bloated or GI dysfunction with inflammation. A carnivore diet is an elimination diet. Let’s assume that on the carnivore diet your biomarkers of inflammation improved, and symptoms improved.

title: Adding Plants Back to Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne thinks once people have eliminated all plants from their diet, the next step should be adding things back in 1 by 1 to figure out what is actually causing problems.

title: Meat and Vegetable Intake
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Most people who eat high amounts of animal protein aren’t eating lean cuts of sirloin and chicken breast. Instead they’re eating high amounts of processed meat and less amounts of fruits and vegetables. Going from high to low vegetable intake there was a liner effect on the incidence of cancer. Eating more meat also shows a linear effect on the incidence of cancer when you don’t correct for fruit and vegetable intake. In those who had the highest intake of meat along with the highest intake of fruits and vegetables there was no effect on cancer incidence. Layne’s takeaway: “That suggests it’s less about the meat you’re eating and what you’re eating it instead of… I like high quality protein… but for God’s sake, have some fruits and vegetables with it because it’s what’s going to mitigate your risk.”

title: Fiber Intake
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne eats a lot of riced cauliflower, broccoli, beans, apples. Berries tend to be really fiber dense compared to apples. Bananas have relatively low fiber, but even the higher sugar, lower fiber fruits are still associated with good health outcomes. He loves popcorn; it’s high fiber. For 50 g of carbohydrate, it will take you 20-30 minutes to eat it and it helped him control his hunger. You get 6-10 g fiber depending on the brand. It’s probably not as healthy as some fruits and vegetables, but as far as snacks go, it’s pretty good and very filling.

title: The Importance of Fiber
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne and Paul Saladino were discussing the importance of fiber in one's diet. Layne believes that fiber has a consistent effect across all meta-analysis and helps reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease and cancer. The RDA for fiber is 20-30 g, and Layne recommends shooting for 15 g per 1000 calories. While processed bars may be better than nothing, Layne believes that getting fiber from real food is better than getting it from a processed bar.

title: Confusion around Omega-6 Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids and the Minnesota Coronary Experiment
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter notes that there is nothing in nutrition that he is more confused about than the role of Omega-6 PUFAs. The Minnesota Coronary Experiment was a unique study that was conducted in a mental facility where the subjects were fed every meal. The study had a big reduction in saturated fat, and corn oil was used to replace cooking oil and used in many foods. The hypothesis being tested was that the group on the lower saturated fat diet should have fewer cardiovascular events. The results of the study were not published until 16 years later.

title: Saturated Fats and Cholesterol
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Peter's interpretation of a study 10 years ago was that saturated fats are not causing heart disease, but now his interpretation is that the study wasn’t long enough to see a difference. In this study, they measured total cholesterol levels but didn’t fractionate cholesterol, so they couldn’t measure LDL or HDL. Still, there was a 30 mg/dL reduction in total cholesterol in the low saturated fat group. Peter’s interpretation now is that a 2-year intervention is not long enough. The modifications you can make to cholesterol from diet (in some cases) can be quite small compared to what you can get with pharmaceutical interventions.

title: PUFAs and Cardiovascular Events
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Ramsden’s data suggests that people in the PUFA (polyunsaturated fatty acid) group had worse outcomes. This throws Peter for a loop and is why he wants to have Chris Ramsden on the podcast. If the details of that study are consistent, it would be the most damning evidence against N6 PUFAs in terms of lowering lipids but raising cardiac events. There’s a precedent for this, a drug (triparanol) approved in the 60s lowered cholesterol but increased cardiovascular events (it was withdrawn). Ramsden proposes a series of mechanisms by which that might be the case with at least this polyunsaturated fat. Conversely, there is a lot of epidemiology that says the opposite, that whenever you substitute saturated for polyunsaturated fats, things get better.

title: Distribution of Fats in the Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne has seen some epidemiology that showed PUFAs were lowering events more. They are more favorable than SFA. Studies that have swayed his opinion were those that had other contextual data where their findings made sense. One study came out and concluded they don’t know how to reconcile their findings because the mechanisms proposed for Omega-6 fats are they will increase inflammation because their double bonds can be oxidized. The oxidation causes inflammation. But if you look at the hard outcome data and RCTs where they give oleic or alpha linoleic acid, you don’t see inflammation go up if they’re not increasing total calories. In particular, if they replace it for saturated fat, you sometimes see inflammation go down.

title: Potential Consequences of High Linoleic Acid Intake
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: It’s been a long time since Peter looked through the BMJ paper (Minnesota coronary experiment), but he recalls a figure that walks through the proposed mechanisms (shown below). What have we added to our diet in the last 20-30 years? When you think of cutting something out, you replace it with other things.

title: The Biggest Contribution to Added Calories in the Diet
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne thinks the biggest contribution to added calories in the diet in the last 20-30 years is oils. The big demon right now is seed oils. As people wanted to make saturated fat a “good guy,” seed oils became the “bad guy”. We never ate seed oils 120 years ago. Today they’re a huge part of our fat calories and look at all the things that are wrong with the world today. It’s the same story for sugar. We ate this much sugar in 1900 and this much in 2000. Look what got worse. Layne’s takeaway: I think when you look through the data and try to be unbiased about it, the continuous boogeyman is just energy toxicity. Problems arise when you’re dealing with extra energy.

title: The Forms of Restriction for Losing Fat or Controlling Body Weight
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The bigger picture is, “If you want to lose fat or control body weight, you have to practice some form of restriction”. You can pick the form of restriction you want. 1 – Restrict calories. Restrict portion size. 2 – Restrict time. 3 – Restrict a certain macronutrient group. 4 – Only eat minimally processed food. For Layne, the easiest thing is to eat what he wants within reason (control the amount). If you do that, you’re going to have to track calories or macros or whatever. What’s interesting is none of these forms of restriction seem to be better than another in terms of adherence at a population level. “Choose the form of restriction that feels the least restrictive for you”‒ Layne Norton.

title: The Psychology of Binge Eating
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne had Professor Jake Linardon on his podcast a while back (an expert in eating disorders), and he said 2 theres are essential for an eating disorder to emerge. 1 – Some sort of poor body image perception. 2 – Hard food rules. So when you create hard food rules, it just does a weird thing in your mind. Binging just means overeating, but Layne doesn’t know the actual criteria. It’s periods of intense food consumption followed by a lot of guilt. We’re not talking about having an extra cookie. We’re talking about eating a whole box of Oreos. For Layne the rules for what was clean to eat seemed very arbitrary. The Bodybuilding Magazine said he couldn’t have sugar or this or that. As he started to avoid these “bad foods” he actually started eating more of them because when he was exposed to them he wasn’t able to moderate it.

title: Flexible Dieting and Portion Control
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton began practicing flexible dieting which involves tracking macros and controlling portion size. He was able to modulate his body composition by eating foods he still enjoyed but controlling portion size.

title: Clean Eating vs Flexible Dieting
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: About 7-8 years ago, Layne Norton was going to debate a bodybuilding coach about clean eating versus flexible dieting. In his opening argument, Layne compared the weekly calories of his meals to the calories the coach ate each week (including junk food). Layne’s point was that the coach was telling him it was really bad to have a cookie, but if he binged on it 1 day a week, that’s okay. This seemed like an odd metric.

title: Tracking and Weighing Food
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: All forms of restriction have downsides. With flexible dieting, you have to keep track of what you eat. Data on food reporting consistently show people underreport by 50%. Even if you don’t practice flexible dieting, tracking and weighing every single thing you put in your mouth for a week is an incredibly valuable tool because it will teach you about portion control and you’ll learn more about nutrition in that week than you would doing anything else. Layne’s app is different from a calorie tracking app because it gives you macros to eat based on your dietary preference and goals. It will adjust them based on how you’re progressing, so it’s not just a one and done calculation.

title: The Benefits of Tracking Your Food Intake
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne emphasizes the importance of tracking your food intake, even if it's just for a week, to learn about portion sizes and calorie intake. He believes that monitoring what you eat can help change your behavior and lead to weight loss. Layne also mentions that tracking is a useful tool when preparing for a bodybuilding show, but it requires a lot of sacrifice and restriction. He encourages people to try tracking their food intake to learn more about their eating habits.

title: The Challenges of Bodybuilding Show Preparation
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne discusses the challenges of preparing for a bodybuilding show, including the need to track food intake with precision and sacrifice social outings. He notes that bodybuilding can have negative effects on hormones and mood, and that powerlifting may be a better alternative. Layne is currently taking a break from bodybuilding to focus on his business and personal passions.

title: Testosterone Levels and Caloric Intake
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne has measured his testosterone probably half a dozen times in the last 5 years. The lowest has been 900. The highest was almost 1100. When he was competing in bodybuilding, it was under 300 when he was close to a show. At his level of lean mass, 1900 calories a day, 260 g protein, around 100 g carbohydrate (or less), 30-40 g fat. Egg whites, chicken breast, some fat-free Greek yogurt. You have to be very careful with your fats when you’re that low calorie. Even eating something that has 7 g of fat (which by all accounts is a low fat item), you have to be careful because those grams can sneak up very quickly. Can you have nuts? Oh, no.

title: Low Energy and Contest Prep
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: “Think about the hungriest you’ve ever been in your life and now imagine that feeling doesn’t leave you for weeks and the lowest energy”‒ Layne Norton. Before a show he struggles with very low energy. He remembers sitting on the couch after training, the remote control was probably 5 feet away, and the Real Housewives was playing (a show he abhors). He sat and watched the entire show because he was not willing to get up and get the remote. That’s how exhausted he was. How many weeks were you into calorie restriction at that point? 20 weeks in (not at 1900 calories). His calories have progressively come down. It’s a body fat issue. He’s had clients who were able to eat higher calories and get really lean. At a certain point of body fat, it doesn’t matter if you are lean and your leptin is low, your testosterone is low. Eric Helms describes contest prep as like you’re circling a drain and you’re just trying to delay going down the drain as long as possible, but eventually you go down the drain.

title: Training and Nutrition during Contest Prep
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The best way to describe it‒ think of getting toothpaste out of the tube. It’s easy with a fresh tube. But as that toothpaste tube gets emptier and emptier, you have to expend more and more effort to squeeze out that last little bit of toothpaste. Contest prep is very much like that. But you do have times when you have energy because you still have to train 2-3 hours a day. The part of contest prep Layne despises is he gets to a point where he doesn’t like training anymore. He continues with it for energy expenditure and to retain muscle. He loses his passion for it, and he’s somebody who loves to train (it’s his favorite thing in the world). He did periodize his nutrition so he would have some higher calorie days on days that were more demanding for training. These were usually lower body training days. As far as getting on stage, one thing he never cuts for bodybuilding shows is water. A lot of people cut water. Layne thinks this is silly because a muscle is 70% water and in your native state you keep more water inside your muscle cell than you do outside your muscle cell. If you begin removing more fluid via a diuretic or fluid restriction/ sodium restriction, you remove it in the same proportion from the subcutaneous layer and the intracellular layer. All you’re going to do is become flatter overall. In the intravascular layer, you get hypertensive. Not cutting water helped Layne with his energy. He was never dehydrated. He didn’t cut sodium or take a diuretic.

title: Water and Sodium Intake for Muscle Fullness
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne points to the example of Georges St-Pierre, when he weighed in, he looked gaunt. He didn’t look healthy, not very muscular. And then the day of the fight (24 hours later), he looked like a bodybuilder. That shows you what drinking water, eating enough sodium and carbohydrate will do for your muscle fullness because muscles are 70% water. Layne thinks not beating his body up with fluid restriction helped him have a little more longevity in bodybuilding/powerlifting.

title: Peak Week Nutrition
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: During peak week, food went back up. On the day of the show he’ll have 300-400 g carbohydrate. If you’re still trying to lose body fat that close to a show, it’s probably not going to go well for you. In peak week, he’ll usually start to feel better as opposed to worse.

title: Aging and Resistance Training
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne thinks resistance training is one of the best things you can to to keep you young. Some of the bodybuilders out there still look really good into their 50s if they continue to do it. Jay Cutler is in his 40s. He trains every day and still eats really well. Layne feels fortunate in that he has had multiple identities. Academic, influencer, entrepreneur, powerlifter, bodybuilder, scientist, a dad. He thinks it will be a little easier for him because he already has other things he cares about. Of course it will be hard, nobody whose successful doesn’t have any ego whatsoever. His goal is not to be the guy who benched 405 (or whatever it is) or squatted 600 until his knees hurt. He will still always lift, always train. He loves it too much not to do it. It makes him feel good.

title: Comparison of muscle activation and kinematics during free-weight back squats with different loads
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study compares muscle activation and kinematics during free-weight back squats with different loads.

title: Australian study of a simple lifting program for older women with osteoporosis
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study shows that high-intensity resistance and impact training improves bone mineral density and physical function in postmenopausal women with osteopenia and osteoporosis.

title: Mouse study found muscle growth boosted by previous exposure to testosterone
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study found that muscle growth is boosted by previous exposure to testosterone due to a cellular memory mechanism that aids overload hypertrophy in muscle long after an episodic exposure to anabolic steroids.

title: Supplementing with creatine increased DHT
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study shows that supplementing with creatine increased DHT to testosterone ratio in college-aged rugby players.

title: Meta-analysis of creatine supplementation
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This meta-analysis examines the importance of creatine ingestion strategies on lean tissue mass and strength in older adults.

title: Initial research on the idea of time under tension
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study examines how muscle time under tension during resistance exercise stimulates differential muscle protein sub-fractional synthetic responses in men.

title: Studies on fast eccentrics versus slow eccentrics found a little better outcome for fast eccentrics with respect to muscle mass
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: These studies found that fast eccentrics versus slow eccentrics have a little better outcome with respect to muscle mass and greater muscle damage is induced by fast versus slow velocity eccentric exercise.

title: Episode of The Drive with Jeremy Loenneke
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This episode of The Drive with Jeremy Loenneke discusses the science of blood flow restriction, its benefits, uses, and what it teaches us about the relationship between muscle size and strength.

title: Long isometric contraction produces hypertrophy
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study shows that skeletal muscle hypertrophy is produced in response to isometric, lengthening, and shortening training bouts of equivalent duration.

title: Episode of The Drive with Don Layman
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This episode of The Drive with Don Layman discusses dietary protein, the amount needed, ideal timing, quality, and more.

title: Layne’s conversation with Thomas DeLauer
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This conversation between Layne Norton and Thomas DeLauer discusses low carb, keto, CICO, and more.

title: Minnesota heart study and re-evaluation of the traditional diet-heart hypothesis
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: These studies test the effect of lipid lowering by diet on cardiovascular risk and re-evaluate the traditional diet-heart hypothesis.

title: Australian heart study: Coronary risk factor screening and long-term follow up
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study focuses on coronary risk factor screening and long-term follow up.

title: Layne’s supplement company: Outwork Nutrition
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton owns a supplement company called Outwork Nutrition.

title: Consumption of meat with fruits and vegetables and incidence of cancer
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This study found that co-consumption of vegetables and fruit, whole grains, and fiber reduces the cancer risk of red and processed meat.

title: Meta-analysis of animal protein intake and mortality
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: This meta-analysis found that animal protein intake is inversely associated with mortality in older adults.

title: ODYSSEY trial of PCSK9 inhibitor
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The ODYSSEY trial studied the efficacy and safety of Alirocumab in reducing lipids and cardiovascular events.

title: FOURIER trials of PCSK9 inhibitor
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: The FOURIER trials studied Evolocumab and clinical outcomes in patients with cardiovascular disease.

title: Layne Norton, Ph.D.
context: Training principles for mass and strength, changing views on nutrition, creatine supplementation, and more.
content: Layne Norton is a Ph.D. in nutritional sciences, a natural pro bodybuilder, professional powerlifter, and a physique coach. He founded BioLayne to provide science-based coaching and has won numerous bodybuilding and powerlifting competitions.
